questions.question: What is a Bounded Context in DDD?

options.text: A linguistic and semantic boundary within which a particular domain model is valid

questions.explanation: Bounded Contexts are the linguistic and semantic boundaries within which a particular domain model is valid. Without bounded contexts, large systems become unmaintainable tangles of conflicting concepts.

questions.question: What problem does having one 'Customer' model serve all contexts create?

options.text: Performance issues due to model size
Every change affects all contexts, unclear field ownership, teams step on each other

questions.explanation: When one model tries to serve all contexts: every change affects all contexts, it's unclear which fields matter where, different teams step on each other, and it's impossible to understand what 'Customer' really means.

questions.question: In bounded contexts, it's acceptable for 'Customer' to mean different things in different contexts (Sales vs Support).
questions.explanation: Each bounded context has its own model with its own definition of concepts. A Sales Customer (with creditLimit) is different from a Support Customer (with ticketCount, satisfactionScore). This is intentional and correct.

questions.question: What is the benefit of having separate Customer models in Sales and Support contexts?

options.text: Each context can evolve independently with only relevant fields and behaviors

questions.explanation: Separate models allow each context to evolve independently, contain only relevant fields (Sales Customer has creditLimit, Support Customer has satisfactionScore), and have behaviors specific to that context.

questions.question: Bounded contexts should always share a common database schema to ensure data consistency.
questions.explanation: Bounded contexts typically have their own data storage and models. Sharing database schemas creates tight coupling and defeats the purpose of bounded contexts. Each context owns its data.
